subject: Re: [junit] Re: newbie question
msgSnippet: jsmitthers, How are you running the tests?  (command line?  Eclipse?  ant?)  Can you copy and paste the output?  Thanks, David Saff
messageBody:
jsmitthers,

How are you running the tests? (command line? Eclipse? ant?) Can
you copy and paste the output? Thanks,

David Saff

On Sun, Dec 26, 2010 at 9:14 PM, <jsmitthers@...> wrote:
> I am now completely confused....
>
> I copy/pasted that test class for testing a different method (I only changed the filename, classname, and a few other necessities), and the new test class worked fantastically....
>
> Then, I added an assertion message to the assert in the test I sent you. It doesn't print the assertion message.
>
> Here is the failing test class:
>
> package blah.Test;
>
> import java.util.LinkedList;
> import org.junit.runners.Parameterized;
> import org.junit.Before;
> import org.junit.Test;
> import org.junit.runner.RunWith;
> import static org.junit.Assert.assertEquals;
> import static org.junit.Assert.assertFalse;
> import static org.junit.Assert.assertTrue;
>
> import blah.blahImpl;
>
> @RunWith(value = Parameterized.class)
> public class blahTestPossibleCard {
>        private blahImpl blahInstance;
>        private String card;
>        private Boolean expectedValidation;
>        private String message;
>
>        @Before
>        public void initialize() {
>                blahInstance = new blahImpl();
>        }
>
>        public blahTestPossibleCard(String card, Boolean expectedValidation, String message) {
>                this.card = card;
>                this.expectedValidation = expectedValidation;
>                this.message = message;
>        }
>
>        @...
>        public static LinkedList<Object[]> possibleCards() {
>                LinkedList<Object[]> possibleCards = new LinkedList<Object[]>();
>                String[] ranks = {"a","k","q","j","10","9","8","7","6","5","4","3","2"};
>                String[] suits = {"s","h","d","c"};
>                for(String rank:ranks)
>                        for(String suit:suits)
>                                possibleCards.add(new Object[] {rank+suit, true, "Valid card '" + rank+suit + "'"});
>                possibleCards.add(new Object[] {"a1",new Boolean(false), "Invalid card 'a1'"});
>                possibleCards.add(new Object[] {"s1",new Boolean(false), "Invalid card 's1'"});
>                possibleCards.add(new Object[] {"s1a",new Boolean(false), "Invalid card 's1a'"});
>                possibleCards.add(new Object[] {"as1",new Boolean(false), "Invalid card 'as1a'"});
>                possibleCards.add(new Object[] {"0000",new Boolean(false), "Invalid card '0000'"});
>                possibleCards.add(new Object[] {"-1",new Boolean(false), "Invalid card '-1'"});
>                possibleCards.add(new Object[] {"a9",new Boolean(false), "Invalid card 'a9'"});
>                possibleCards.add(new Object[] {"10",new Boolean(false), "Invalid card '10'"});
>                possibleCards.add(new Object[] {"a",new Boolean(false), "Invalid card 'a'"});
>                possibleCards.add(new Object[] {"10sh",new Boolean(false), "Invalid card '10sh'"});
>                return possibleCards;
>        }
>
>        @Test
>        public void testPossibleCards() {
>                System.out.println("Testing value '"+card+"' with expected result '" +expectedValidation + "'");
>                assertEquals(message, expectedValidation, blahInstance.possibleCard(card));
>                //assertEquals(expectedValidation.booleanValue(),blahInstance.possibleCard(card));
>        }
> }
>
>
> --- In junit@yahoogroups.com, jsmitthers@... wrote:
>>
>>
>>
>> Hi David, Thanks for the help! I'm very new to this, so I'm sure this is not the most efficient method of testing.
>>
>> blahImpl.possibleCard(String card) returns either true or false if the card presented is valid. For example, "10s" is valid (10 of spades), "11s" is invalid, "3h" is valid.
>>
>> Instead of using the Boolean class, I've also tried using a plain old boolean. Both produce the same results. Interestingly, when running, the println() statements show that the boolean value is being carried over into testPossibleCards().
>>
>> This test is being executed by Hudson, via Ant, using javac version 1.6.0_22 on an ubuntu server system. I've never used JUnit, Ant, or Hudson... I jumped in head first :).
>>
>> Anyways, enough yacking on my part. Here is my attempt:
>>
>> package blah.Test;
>>
>> import java.util.LinkedList;
>> import org.junit.runners.Parameterized;
>> import org.junit.Before;
>> import org.junit.Test;
>> import org.junit.runner.RunWith;
>> import static org.junit.Assert.assertEquals;
>> import static org.junit.Assert.assertFalse;
>> import static org.junit.Assert.assertTrue;
>>
>> import blah.blahImpl;
>>
>> @RunWith(value = Parameterized.class)
>> public class blahTestPossibleCard {
>>       private blahImpl blahInstance;
>>       private String card;
>>       private Boolean expectedValidation;
>>
>>       @Before
>>       public void initialize() {
>>               blahInstance = new blahImpl();
>>       }
>>
>>       public blahTestPossibleCard(String card, Boolean expectedValidation) {
>>               this.card = card;
>>               this.expectedValidation = expectedValidation;
>>               System.out.println("init " + expectedValidation.booleanValue());
>>       }
>>
>>       @...
>>       public static LinkedList<Object[]> possibleCards() {
>>               LinkedList<Object[]> possibleCards = new LinkedList<Object[]>();
>>               String[] ranks = {"a","k","q","j","10","9","8","7","6","5","4","3","2"};
>>               String[] suits = {"s","h","d","c"};
>>               for(String rank:ranks)
>>                       for(String suit:suits)
>>                               possibleCards.add(new Object[] {new String(rank+suit), true});
>>               possibleCards.add(new Object[] {"a1",new Boolean(false)});
>>               possibleCards.add(new Object[] {"s1",new Boolean(false)});
>>               possibleCards.add(new Object[] {"s1a",new Boolean(false)});
>>               possibleCards.add(new Object[] {"as1",new Boolean(false)});
>>               possibleCards.add(new Object[] {"0000",new Boolean(false)});
>>               possibleCards.add(new Object[] {"-1",new Boolean(false)});
>>               possibleCards.add(new Object[] {"a9",new Boolean(false)});
>>               possibleCards.add(new Object[] {"10",new Boolean(false)});
>>               possibleCards.add(new Object[] {"a",new Boolean(false)});
>>               possibleCards.add(new Object[] {"10sh",new Boolean(false)});
>>               return possibleCards;
>>       }
>>
>>       @Test
>>       public void testPossibleCards() {
>>
>>               if(expectedValidation) {
>>                       System.out.println("at used " + expectedValidation.booleanValue());
>>                       assertTrue(blahInstance.possibleCard(card));
>>               } else {
>>                       System.out.println("af used " + expectedValidation.booleanValue());
>>                       assertFalse(blahInstance.possibleCard(card));
>>               }
>>               //assertEquals(expectedValidation.booleanValue(),blahInstance.possibleCard(card));
>>       }
>> }
>>
>> THANKS!!
>>
>> --- In junit@yahoogroups.com, David Saff <david@> wrote:
>> >
>> > Hi, jsmitthers.
>> >
>> > There are a few bugs that need to be fixed where JUnit adds "null" to
>> > failure messages.  However, I'm not aware of any that result in
>> > exactly that message.  Can you post a small test class that I can run
>> > to see this behavior?  Thanks,
>> >
>> >    David
>> >
>> > On Sat, Dec 25, 2010 at 3:00 PM, jsmitthers <jsmitthers@> wrote:
>> > > I'm learning about using junit for my unit tests. My problem is that while my test is written as:
>> > >
>> > > assertTrue(blahInstance.possibleCard(card));
>> > >
>> > > I'm getting the following:
>> > >
>> > > expected:<null> but was:<true>
>> > >
>> > > blahInstance.possibleCard(String card) returns a boolean. But why am I getting expected null when I'm doing an assertTrue?
>> > >
>> > > I've tried junit 4.8.2 and 4.8.1 with no change. I have a parameterized test going where it runs a bunch of assertTrue based off a parameter. Every time it tests I get the same expected:<null>.
>> > >
>> > > At first I had assertEquals with that error, so I changed it to assertTrue or assertFalse and I'm still getting expected:<null>.
>> > >
>> > > What am I doing wrong?
>> > >
>> > >
>> > >
>> > > ------------------------------------
>> > >
>> > > Yahoo! Groups Links
>> > >
>> > >
>> > >
>> > >
>> >
>>
>
>
